AF Casado, L. G.
   Martinez, J. A.
   Garcia, I.
   Hendrix, E. M. T.
TI Branch-and-bound interval global optimization on shared memory
   multiprocessors
SO OPTIMIZATION METHODS & SOFTWARE
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 2nd International Conference on Optimization Methods and Software/6th
   EUROPT Workshop on Advances in Continuous Optimization
CY JUL 04-07, 2007
CL Prague, CZECH REPUBLIC
DE global optimization; branch-and-bound; interval arithmetic; parallel
   algorithms; shared memory; multithreading
ID PARALLELIZATION
AB The focus of this paper is on the analysis and evaluation of a type of parallel strategies applied to the algorithm Advanced Multidimensional Interval analysis Global Optimization (AMIGO). We investigate two parallel versions of AMIGO, called Parallel AMIGO (PAMIGO) algorithm, Global-PAMIGO and Local-PAMIGO. The idea behind our study is that in order to exploit the potential parallelism of algorithms, researchers need to adapt them to the target computer architectures. Our PAMIGO algorithms have been designed for shared memory architectures and are based on a threaded programming model, which is suitable to be run on current personal computers with multicore processors. Our first experimental results show a promising speed-up up to four process units. We analyse the loss of efficiency when the number of process units is greater than four by obtaining a profile of the algorithm executions. Secondly we experiment with the use of a local memory allocator per thread. This increases the efficiency by reducing the number of lock conflicts given by the standard system memory allocator. Our experimental results for both PAMIGO versions, using up to 15 process units, obtain a good performance for hard to solve problems on unicore and multicore processors. It is noteworthy that both versions of PAMIGO obtain a similar performance. Our experiments may be useful for researchers who use parallel BB algorithms.
C1 [Casado, L. G.; Martinez, J. A.; Garcia, I.] Univ Almeria, Dept Comp Architecture & Elect, Almeria, Spain.
   [Hendrix, E. M. T.] Univ Malaga, Dept Comp Architecture, Malaga, Spain.

TI Optimal flight trajectories for the validation of aerodynamic models
SO OPTIMIZATION METHODS & SOFTWARE
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT International Workshop on Parameter Estimation and Experimental Design
CY JUN 30-JUL 02, 2004
CL Heidelberg, GERMANY
DE optimum experimental design; optimal control; trajectory optimization
ID NUMERICAL-METHODS; DESIGN; SYSTEMS
AB For the validation of aerodynamic models, certain flight trajectories have to be chosen. In the current paper, the methodology of optimum experimental design is employed for the solution of this task. Aerodynamic models are highly nonlinear and so far no optimum experimental design approaches have been applied to them. We show that the methods of optimum experimental design are efficiently applicable to such models and considerably improve the statistical accuracy of the parameter estimates.
C1 Univ Trier, Dept Math, FB 4, D-54286 Trier, Germany.
   Boeing Co, Math & Engn Anal, Seattle, WA 98124 USA.

TI Dynamical approaches and multi-quadratic integer programming for seizure
   prediction
SO OPTIMIZATION METHODS & SOFTWARE
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Workshop on Mathematical Diagnostics
CY JUN, 2002
CL E Majorana Ctr Sci Culture, G Stampacchia Sch Math, Erice, ITALY
HO E Majorana Ctr Sci Culture, G Stampacchia Sch Math
DE multi-quadratic 0-1 programming problem; dynamical approaches; EEG;
   seizure prediction
ID BRAIN ELECTRICAL-ACTIVITY; TIME-SERIES ANALYSIS; EPILEPTIC SEIZURES;
   NONLINEAR-ANALYSIS; EEG RECORDINGS; STATES
AB In this article, we present dynamical approaches and multi-quadratic integer programming techniques to study the problem of seizure prediction. The data used in our studies consist of continuous intracranial electroencephalograms (EEGs) from patients with temporal lobe epilepsy. The results of this study can be used as a criterion to pre-select the critical electrode sites that can be used to predict epileptic seizures.

PT J
AU Mifflin, R
   Sagastizábal, C
AF Mifflin, R
   Sagastizábal, C
TI <i>VU</i>-smoothness and proximal point results for some nonconvex
   functions
SO OPTIMIZATION METHODS & SOFTWARE
LA English
DT Article
DE proximal point; VU-decomposition; second-order derivatives
ID DUAL GRADIENT STRUCTURE; OPTIMALITY CONDITIONS; EPI-DERIVATIVES;
   OPTIMIZATION
AB This article is concerned with a function f having a primal-dual gradient structure at a point (x) over bar which satisfies a property called strong transversality. The structure is related to VU-space decomposition, depending on the subdifferential of fat at (x) over bar. It is shown that there exists a C-2 primal track leading to (x) over bar and a space decomposition mapping that is C-1. As a result, there exists a second-order expansion of f on the primal track, an associated subdifferemial that is C-1 in a certain sense, and a corresponding dual track. For (x) over bar a minimizer, conditions on f are given to ensure that for any point near (x) over bar its corresponding proximal point is on the primal track.
C1 Washington State Univ, Dept Math, Pullman, WA 99164 USA.
C3 Washington State University

TI An iterative method for solving stochastic Riccati differential
   equations for the stochastic LQR problem
SO OPTIMIZATION METHODS & SOFTWARE
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 1st International Conference on Optimization Methods and Software
   (OMS2002)
CY DEC 15-18, 2002
CL HANGZHOU, PEOPLES R CHINA
SP Natl Natural Sci Fdn China, Timless Software Ltd, Owlet Techcom Ltd, Taylor & Francis Journals Ltd, Zhejiang Univ, City Univ Hong Kong
DE stochastic Riccati differential equations; linear differential equation;
   stochastic linear quadratic regulator
ID LINEAR-QUADRATIC REGULATORS; CONTROL WEIGHT COSTS; SYSTEMS
AB This paper develops an iterative method for solving stochastic Riccati differential equations for stochastic linear quadratic regulator (LQR) problems some of which may be even with indefinite control weight costs. We obtain a sequence of solutions of linear matrix differential equations which converges uniformly to the solution of a stochastic Riccati differential equation.

TI A globally convergent method of moving asymptotes with trust region
   technique
SO OPTIMIZATION METHODS & SOFTWARE
LA English
DT Article
DE method of moving asymptotes; trust region method; structural
   optimization
ID MINIMIZATION; ALGORITHMS
AB The method of moving asymptotes is known to work well for certain problems arising in structural optimization. A globally convergent method of moving asymptotes with trust region technique is proposed in this paper. A convex separable subproblem is solved in each iteration. The choice of asymptotes is controlled by the trust region radius such that global convergence of the algorithm is obtained. In addition, preliminary numerical tests are given.

PT J
AU Pintér, JD
AF Pintér, JD
TI Globally optimized calibration of nonlinear models:: Techniques,
   software, and applications
SO OPTIMIZATION METHODS & SOFTWARE
LA English
DT Article
DE model calibration; nonlinear (convex and global) optimization; LGO model
   development and solver system; LGO solver engine for Excel users;
   MathOptimizer for Mathematica users; illustrative numerical examples and
   case studies
AB The search for a better understanding of complex systems calls for quantitative model development. Within this process, model fitting to observation data often plays an important role. Traditionally, standard (convex) nonlinear optimization techniques have been applied to solve model calibration problems: the limitations of such approaches - due to their local search scope - are well known. By contrast, global optimization (GO) strategies are able to find (i.e., to numerically approximate) the 'absolutely best' model parameterization. This point is illustrated by numerical examples and case studies which have been analyzed and solved by our various software implementations.

PT J
AU Eppler, K
   Harbrecht, H
AF Eppler, K
   Harbrecht, H
TI Numerical solution of elliptic shape optimization problems using
   wavelet-based BEM
SO OPTIMIZATION METHODS & SOFTWARE
LA English
DT Article
DE shape optimization; boundary element method; multiscale methods; penalty
   and augmented Lagrangian approach; gradient and Quasi-Newton method
ID OPTIMALITY; ALGORITHMS
AB In this article we study the numerical solution of elliptic shape optimization problems with additional constraints, given by domain or boundary integral functionals. A special boundary variational approach combined with a boundary integral formulation of the state equation yields shape gradients and functionals which are expressed only in terms of boundary integrals . Hence, the efficiency of (standard) descent optimization algorithms is considerably increased, especially for the line search. We demonstrate our method for a class of problems from planar elasticity, where the stationary domains are given analytically by Banichuk and Karihaloo in [N.V. Banichuk and B.L. Karihaloo (1976). Minimum-weight design of multi-purpose cylindrical bars. International Journal of Solids and Structures , 12 , 267-273.]. In particular, the boundary integral equation is solved by a wavelet Galerkin scheme which offers a powerful tool. For optimization we apply gradient and Quasi-Newton type methods for the penalty as well as for the augmented Lagrangian functional.
C1 Tech Univ Berlin, Math Inst, D-10623 Berlin, Germany.
   Tech Univ Chemnitz, Fak Math, D-09107 Chemnitz, Germany.
C3 Technical University of Berlin; Technische Universitat Chemnitz
RP Eppler, K (corresponding author), Tech Univ Berlin, Math Inst, Str 17 Juni 135, D-10623 Berlin, Germany.
